newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai B share index ends down on A share drop.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai B share index ends down on A share drop.

text.p: Shanghai's B share index lost early gains and ended slightly down on Tuesday due to sharp losses on the A share market, as a result of rumours of a new official crackdown, traders said.
The index lost 0.099 points or 0.15 percent to 64.588 points, on volume of 17.1 million shares worth $8.2 million.
The A index dived 39.179 points or 4.17 percent to 900.767, on volume of 329.9 million shares worth 2.8 billion yuan.
Rumours said Beijing would take new measures against speculation, possibly by adopting a three-day settlement system to replace the current next-day settlement.
The SSE 30 blue-chip index fell 77.336 points or 3.18 percent to 2354.363 points. Of 42 B shares, 40 traded, with 18 down, seven flat and 15 up.
Kunming Machine was the biggest loser on expectations of poor results, falling 0.39 yuan or 10.05 percent to 3.49 yuan, on volume of 1.8 million shares.
Brokers said falls of domestic A shares late in the session sparked liquidation selling in the B share market, with limited institutional support ahead of the Christmas holiday.
"Individual investors dominated trading while major overseas investors enjoyed their holiday," one broker said. "The market has no momentum to rise or fall in the short term."
"The index will continue to move between 63 and 65 points in the next few days until fresh market-moving news emerges," a second broker said.
Shanghai Rubber Belt was the biggest loser, down $0.016 or 6.25 percent to $0.240, on volume of 68,700 shares.
Textile company Worldbest traded the most on institutional unwinding selling, falling $0.002 or 0.55 percent to $0.360, on volume of 1.9 million shares.
Real estate developer Lujiazui bucked the trend on its announcement of a four-for-ten bonus issue, rising $0.026 or 2.13 percent to $1.246, on volume of 1.8 million shares.
